items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels are rising on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to heavy rainfall through the early hours of this morning. Areas most at risk include the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Further rainfall is forecast through till late afternoon, today (Saturday 12/02/22) but no property flooding is expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast and amend this message if necessary. Our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further rainfall tomorrow is possible which might have an effect on these watercourses but the exact pattern of this is not yet clear. This message will be updated on Sunday morning (13/02/2022), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels on Church Beck and watercourses at Coniston have risen in response to rainfall from this morning, Saturday 12/02/22, and Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck are also responding to the rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near these watercourses, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. Localised minor flooding is possible today with further rainfall expected tomorrow morning. Flooding of property is not anticipated and we do not expect to be issuing any Flood Warnings. We will continue to monitor the situation and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, Sunday 13/02/22, or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as conditions have eased and tides have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
